III. 

BACKGROUND

A. 

Sector Description

1.

Urban Development

4.    Mongolia has urbanized rapidly in the last three decades. Major rural-to-urban migration
started during the 1970s, when heavy investments in cities began with financial assistance from
Russia. The urban population grew 4.5 percent in the 1970s, 3.6 percent in the 1980s, and 2.1
percent  in  the  1990s.  While  Ulaanbaatar  has  been  growing  fast,  the  populations  of  smaller
urban  centers  have  been  decreasing  as  their  economic  bases  have  weakened  and  some  ger
households have moved back to the countryside.

5.   
About 59 percent of Mongolia’s 2.5 million population is classified as urban; more than
half  of  the  urban  population  is  in  the  capital,  Ulaanbaatar.  Three  other  cities  were  elevated  to
the  administrative  status  of  a  province  in  May  1994,  bringing  the  total  number  of  provinces  to
21. These are Choir, Darkhan, and Erdenet, which have a combined population of 180,000. The
next  levels  of  settlements  in  the  hierarchy  are  the  18  provincial  capitals  with  an  average
population of 28,000. In addition, about 330 rural districts with an average population of about
2,000,  provide  services  to  the  rural  and  nomadic  populations.  About  35  settlements  are
considered  urban,  with  an  average  population  estimated  at  4,000.  Each  rural  district  is  further
divided into smaller administrative units, usually 4 to 6 subdistricts, each consisting of 70 to 120
families.

6.    Mongolian  cities  present  two  very  distinct  types  of  development.  The  first  involves
planned areas featuring prefabricated or brick apartment blocks from 1 to 10 stories, surrounded
by  vaguely  defined  open  spaces.  The  second  involves  “temporary”  ger  housing  areas
characterized by long strips of large unserviced plots with wide roads on either side, which now
dominates urban growth. The HL recognizes that most new urban development will be guided
by  market  considerations  and  implemented  by  individual  initiatives,  rather  than  by  the
construction  of  subsidized  apartments  in  formally  planned  areas.  While  interest  has  been
growing for community action planning to improve ger housing areas, the approach has yet to
be  formally  adopted.  The  proposed  Project  will  promote  the  bottom-up  HAAP  approach  to
planning based on extensive consultations with the communities and resulting in new planning
procedures and standards for residential development.

2.

Housing Situation

7.    Mongolia’s recent transition to a market economy is focusing attention on the country’s
housing  delivery  system  in  urban  areas.  Until  the  early  1990s,  the  norm  for  new  housing
provision was public sector construction of prefabricated apartment buildings. With the collapse
of the construction industry and the virtual end of public sector housing supply, the incremental
improvement of housing in ger housing areas, beginning with the traditional ger and ending with
a substantial all-weather house, will need to become the predominant path to affordable housing
for low-income households. Also, while over 90 percent of the housing has been privatized, the
housing condition is seriously deteriorating because of inadequate financing for maintenance.

8.    While  there  are  no  official  estimates  of  housing  demand  in  the  country,  the  total
cessation of public housing construction coupled with high migration has led to a rapid growth in
ger  housing  areas  over  the  past  several  years,  especially  in  Ulaanbaatar.  Also,  while  officially
only  one  household  should  be  occupying  each  apartment,  often  more  than  one  household  is
sharing  an  apartment.  Much  ground  floor  housing  has  been  converted  into  cafes,  bars,

 3

restaurants,  shops,  and  offices.  Such  conversions  have  reduced  by  about  15  percent  of  the
apartment  housing  in  Ulaanbaatar.  Housing  demand  is  also  manifested  in  the  number  of  new
ger  housing  area  plots  being  issued  by  the  district  offices  of  Ulaanbaatar  municipality.  Ger
housing  areas  and  the  doubling  up  in  apartments  have  absorbed  most  of  the  population
increase from 1992 to 1998. Based on the population growth and existing land use patterns, ger
housing  areas  in  Ulaanbaatar  increased  by  more  than  2000  hectares  during  1999.  The
development  of  the  housing  sector  plays  a  crucial  role  in  the  transition  to  a  market-based
housing and land system, and in development of urban areas. Accordingly, the Government has
taken  steps  to establish the policy and legal framework for creation of a market-based shelter
and urban services sector.

3.

Housing and Land Markets

9.   
Housing markets are developing with the trade in apartments and the start of trading in
ger  plots.6  Privatized  apartments  and  future  ger  plots  are  potential  sources  of  equity  for
transactions in property. Progress in the development of land markets is slow and will remain so
until land is privatized. However, once private ownership is introduced, ger residents will benefit
from  the  security  brought  about  by  land  registration  and  title  to  their  land,  as  well  as  its  asset
value.  A  major  step  forward  has  been  the  enactment  of  the  Cadastral  Survey  and  Land
Registration  Law  in  1999  and  the  approval  of  the  Cadastral  Survey  and  Land  Registration
Project.7 Apart from providing the basis for securing title, the law can help form the basis for a
much-needed  property-based  taxation  system.  Local  governments  also  have  an  invaluable
resource,  publicly  owned  land,  which  can  benefit  households,  businesses,  and  community
groups  by  providing  for  the  rational  transfer  of  land  to  private  use,  retaining  certain  areas  for
community use and supporting the development of a sustainable land market.

4.

Housing Finance

10.    Despite the housing policy framework, a number of issues will effect the development of
a sustainable housing finance system in Mongolia. The first overriding issue is the complete lack
of experience with housing finance in the country. In the past, Government entities constructed
all  formal  housing,  and  most  rural  families  lived  in  self-financed  gers.  While  some  banks  and
nonbank finance institutions have made small apartment repair and renovation loans, there has
been no term or mortgage lending for housing in Mongolia.

11.    Second,  the  lack  of  mortgage  lending  is  complicated  by  the  lack  of  clarity  in  the  laws
relating to land ownership. For example, the Civil Code currently prohibits the use of land lease
certificates as collateral. However, a proposed new draft of the Land Law is to be considered by
parliament  in  their  October  to  December  2001  session.8  A  third  major  issue  is  the  state  of
development  of  the  banking  system.9  Despite  recent  progress,  the  banking  system  is  still
relatively  fragile  and  feeling  the  effects  of  the  1996  banking  crisis.  Although  the  supporting
financial infrastructure is now largely in place, many of the banks in the system are new, small,
or  do  not  consistently  qualify  according  to  the  prudential  regulations  of  the  Bank  of  Mongolia
(BOM). Term lending beyond one year is rare, with loans to individuals based on large savings

13.   
In  1997,  Parliament  deleted  the  pricing  provision  before  passing  the  Apartment
Privatization Act. For a nominal registration fee, tenants obtained titles to their apartments from
the  Government.  Apartment  units  are  now  sold  on  the  open  market,  creating  an  emerging
residential  property  market.  However,  since  land  is  still  owned  by  the  state,  ger  housing  area
residents only have certificates of occupancy from the local government. These cannot be used
as  collateral  for  housing  improvement  or  construction  loans.  In  addition,  although  ger  housing
area upgrading is a priority intervention in the HL, the institutional arrangements for upgrading
remain  undefined  and  local  government  agencies  have  limited  capacity  for  project  planning,
financing,  and  implementation.  To  assist  in  financing  housing  activities,  the  creation  of  a
national  HDF  is  provided  for  in  the  HL.  According  to  the  law,  HDF  capital  can  be  used  for

Existing Legal Framework

15.    Sustainable  housing  finance  markets  are  based  on  the  collateral  value  of  the  property
being  financed;  and  the  collateral  value  is  influenced  by  the  ability  of  the  lender  to  efficiently
take  possession  and  dispose  of  the  property.  The  existing  legal  framework  allows  for
condominiums,  houses,  and  other  immovable  property  to  be  used  as  collateral  for  loans.  The
approval  by  parliament  of  an  amendment  to  the  Civil  Code  on  2  February  2001,14  authorizes
banks  to  seize  the  collateralized  house  or  apartment  if  the  borrower  fails  to  repay  the  loan,
without  having  to  go  through  cumbersome  court  proceedings.    Also  Article  120.1  of  the  Civil
Code states that owners of a residential house are entitled to possess, use, and dispose of the
property at their discretion and Article 75.3 states that owners may transfer to others their rights
to  possess,  use,  or  dispose  of  these  properties.  Further,  two  ADB  programs  contain
components  to  strengthen  the  legal  framework  underlying  collateralized  lending.  Under  the
FSPII  a  TA15  is  included  to  identify  legal,  regulatory,  and  institutional  deficiencies  and
constraints  to  using  immovable  property  as  collateral.  Also,  the  recently  approved  Cadastral
Survey  and  Land  Registration  Project  includes  TA16  for  a  land  legislation  expert  to  make  a
comprehensive  overview  of  existing  relevant  legislation.  When  undertaking  these  reviews,  the
projects must include basic issues related to the proposed Project such as (i) consideration of
concerned  appropriate  eviction  laws,17  and  (ii)  appropriate  review  of  the  Registration  of
Immovable Property Law to ensure the legal basis for incremental construction lending.

Improve Governance

32.    By  facilitating  homeownership  for  an  increasing  number  of  Mongolian  households,  the

IV.  

THE PROPOSED PROJECT

A.

Rationale

33.    Over  the  past  three  decades,  Mongolia  has  experienced  rapid  urbanization.  Presently,
over half of the population resides in urban areas. However, since the end of the socialist era, in
which  all  housing  was  constructed  by  government  entities,  very  little  new  formal  or  apartment
housing  has  been  built.  Consequently,  ger  housing  areas  that  are  not  provided  with  urban
services surround Mongolian cities, have expanded rapidly, and now comprise about 50 percent
of the housing in most urban areas. Hence, access of the poor to urban services and adequate
housing  continues  to  be  limited.  One  of  the  critical  factors  in  increased  access  to  adequate
housing  and  services  for  the  low-  and  middle-income  families  is  housing  finance,  which  is
practically nonexistent in the country. By establishing and partly funding a sustainable housing
finance system in Mongolia, the proposed Project is the logical next step in the development of
the housing sector after ADB’s successful policy making TA 2890 (footnote 1) and institutional
strengthening TA 3090 (footnote 3).

 11

34.    The  lack  of  long-term  finance,  inadequate  legal  framework  with  respect  to  property
rights,  and  weak  institutional  capacity  has  kept  Mongolian  commercial  banks  from  lending  for
housing. Currently, the major sources of housing finance for all but high-income households is
their own savings and family assets. International experience shows that once low- and middle-
income families obtain sufficient income, their highest priority becomes improving their housing
situation.  The  results  of  primary  surveys  for  the  Project  indicate  an  overwhelming  demand  for
improved housing. Much of the demand is for a completed house, which can be built in the short
construction  season  in  Mongolia.  Once  households  have  access  to  housing  finance,  the  loan
catalyzes releasing the financial and technical resources of family, friends, and relatives.

35.    ADB’s  involvement  in  the  housing  sector  in  Mongolia  is  justified  because  (i)  of  large
demand  for  adequate  housing  and  shelter,  which  is  essential  for  survival  of  the  household,
particularly  for  the  poor,  given  the  extremes  of  the  Mongolian  climate;  (ii)  significant  health
benefits will accrue from better and improved basic infrastructure; (iii) investment in the housing
sector can be designed to achieve full cost recovery to ensure sustainability; and (iv) linkages
will  be  strengthened  between  the  financial,  banking,  housing,  and  construction  sectors,  and
substantial employment will be created in construction.

B.

Objectives and Scope

36.    The  main  objectives  of  the  Project  are  to  (i)  help  to  meet  the  immediate  need  for
adequate  housing  in  Mongolia;  (ii)  contribute  to  the  longer  term  objective  of  establishing  a
sustainable,  market-based  system  for  the  delivery  of  housing  finance  to  meet  the  borrowing
needs  of  low-  and  middle-income  households;  (iii)  reduce  poverty  in  ger  housing  areas  by
providing  and  upgrading  basic  infrastructure  and  services  through  HAAP  schemes;  and  (iv)
improve the quality of life of low- and middle-income urban households by providing affordable
housing loans.

37.    The  proposed  Project  consists  of  three  parts:  A  –  lending  to  low-  and  middle-income
households  through  PCBs  and  intermediaries;  B  –  addressing  poverty  reduction  by  financing
HAAP  schemes  in  ger  housing  areas  and  providing  serviced  plots  for  new  housing;  and  C  –
capacity  building  and  establishing  effective  project  management.  About  60  percent  of  the
lending  under  A  is  expected  to  be  through  intermediaries,  including  private-public  enterprises.
Based  on  survey  results,  the  enterprises  plan  to  construct  apartment  blocks  near  their  plant
sites for employees currently living in ger housing areas, most of whom fall in the low income
bracket.26

effective means of responding to the varying housing finance needs of low- and middle-income
groups.

40.    Thus,  under  part  A  of  the  Project,  PCBs  will  onlend  to  intermediaries  including  mainly

enterprises had a high employee demand for housing loans and indicated that the availability of
such loans would enhance employee morale resulting in higher productivity and profitability. To
prevent  any  negative  impact  on  the  financial  position  of  the  enterprises,  the  subsidiary  loan
agreement will require that borrowings from PCBs cannot exceed 30 percent of an enterprise’s
total  equity.  The  enterprises  have  also  confirmed  that  only  the  registered  certificates  of  the

collateral, and not the enterprises’ productive assets. Further, the title to the apartment or house
will  be  transferred  to  the  employee  only  upon  full  repayment  of  the  loan  on  a  hire  purchase
agreement  basis.  The  Project  will  also  promote  savings  mobilization.  The  PCBs  are  currently
working  out  the  details  for  introducing  housing  savings  accounts  for  subborrowers,  who  after
reaching a certain amount of savings, could then qualify for a loan under the proposed Project.

41.    The  second  category  of  subborrowers  will  be  small-  and  medium-scale  contractors,
which  will  borrow  construction  loans  from  PCBs.  A  third  category  under  part  A,  which  will  not
entail onlending to individual borrowers, will be condominium associations, which will borrow for
apartment  block  maintenance  and  major  repairs.  Lending  to  condominium  associations  is
provided  for  in  the  HL  and  is  a  specified  purpose  of  the  HDF.  Using  the  combined  apartment
titles  of  condominium  association  members  as  collateral,  the  condominium  associations  have
expressed  a  desire  to  access  the  HDF  by  borrowing  from  PCBs  for  these  purposes.
Accordingly,  lending  to  condominium  associations  for  apartment  block  improvement  has  been
provided  for  in  the  latter  years  of  the  Project.    Direct  lending  to  individuals  is  envisaged  from
year  three  onwards,  subject  to  sufficient  development  of  the  PCBs’  housing  finance
departments, including their ability to assess the repayment capacity of prospective borrowers.

43.    Four types of HAAP schemes will be eligible for financing: (i) new HAAPs that focus on
the basic layout of roads and power utility lines at new housing sites to facilitate urban planning

more efficient use of existing infrastructure to provide fully serviced plots that can be auctioned
to builders of private sector housing; (iii) simple upgrading HAAPs that include relatively small
improvements  to  ger  housing  areas  to  initiate  a  process  of  incremental,  community-based
improvement  in  these  areas;  and  (iv)  complex  upgrading  HAAPs  that  include  more  extensive
physical and economic improvements to larger ger housing areas. In-fill and upgrading HAAPs
will be implemented together to provide affordable serviced plots for new housing construction
that may be funded under part A.

44.    A  total  of  18  HAAP  schemes  are  to  be  implemented  under  the  Project  in  the  cities  of
Darkhan,  Zuunmod,  and  Ulaanbaatar,  benefiting  about  7,000  households.  Under  TA  3090
(footnote  3),  HAAP  pilot  projects  were  designed  for  the  three  concerned  cities.  These
subprojects  will  be  included  in  the  first  HAAP  applications  under  the  proposed  loan.  The  two
advanced  pilot  projects  in  Darkhan  and  Zuunmod  include  both  in-fill  and  ger  housing  area
upgrading  components.  The  in-fill  project  in  Darkhan  will  provide  about  200  serviced  plots  of
different  sizes  that  will  be  affordable  to  low-  and  middle-income  households.  The  complex
upgrading  project  will  include  seven  water  supply  kiosks,  road  grading  and  improvement,
footpaths, drainage control, and street lighting for more than 850 families living adjacent to the
city center. Water supply will involve piped water to existing and new kiosks with the pipes sized
to  allow  for  individual  metered  connections  along  the  way.  The  pilot  project  in  Zuunmod  is
smaller in scope, involving, (i) 127 serviced, in-fill plots32 in the city center, and (ii) the provision
of  piped  water  to  kiosks,  and  drainage  and  road  grading  in  a  small  ger  housing  area  of  200
families.  While  the  pilot  projects  in  Ulaanbaatar  remain  to  be  finalized,  they  are  also  likely  to
include both in-fill and ger upgrading activities.

45.    The newness of the HAAP approach and limited capacity of Mongolian cities to engage
capital  investments  will  generally  keep  the  size  of  the  first  in-fill  HAAPs  to  less  than  300  plots

Zuunmod, where more than a thousand households have applied for one of the 117 infill plots.

upgrading.  Darkhan  has  similarly  agreed  to  auction  its  infill  sites.  City  governments  will
contribute 25 percent of the cost of the in-fill projects.

4. 

Linkage Between Parts A and B of the Project

50.    The most apparent linkage between parts A and B will be the provision of serviced sites
for the construction and improvement of housing financed by loans through part A. Virtually no
provisions were made for private individual housing under the previous centralized planning and
state  run  approach  to  housing  and  urban  development.  Master  plans  produced  in  the  early
1980s  focused  almost  exclusively  on  the  construction  of  large-scale,  multistory  apartment
blocks  by  state-owned  companies.  Most  of  these  master  plans  have  expired  and  efforts  are
under way to develop new ones. The new master plans will place considerable emphasis on the
construction of individual, private sector housing based on the Government’s housing policy.

 15

51.    The HAAP approach, directly supported by part B of the Project, will provide an effective
means  to  introduce  new  planning  procedures  and  standards  for  residential  development.  The
Housing  Law  enables  HAAPs  to  become  integral  components  of  city  master  plans  and  to
supercede previous planning requirements in areas where they are applied. The application of
new HAAP sites in rapidly growing Ulaanbaatar will enable the city to begin to control its rapid
growth  and  to  provide  more  secure  land  tenure  for  low  income  housing  construction  in  areas
where  trunk  infrastructure  is  not  yet  in  place.  HAAP  in-fill  sites  will  also  provide  fully  serviced
plots  for  households  seeking  to  build  private  sector  housing,  including  those  obtaining  a  loan
under part A. The new master plans for several cities will be linked to the provision of residential
infrastructure  and  to  the  upgrading  of  existing  neighborhoods.  Part  B  is  the  first  broad-based
attempt  to  address  these  concerns  in  cities  of  all  sizes  and  to  establish  a  new,  market-based
working  arrangement  between  city  planning  and  private-public  investment.  Experience  gained
through the implementation of the Project and the financing of HAAPs will help Mongolian cities
to plan their development in a more effective manner.

PROJECT JUSTIFICATION

96.    The lack of finance to build new or improve existing housing in Mongolia has led to an
alarming deterioration in the formal housing stock and the rapid growth of informal ger housing
areas,  both  of  which  directly  affect  the  quality  of  life  of  low-income  households.  While  low-
income  households 
in  apartments  have  experienced  a  deterioration  of  services  and
infrastructure,  those  in  ger  housing  areas  have  minimal  services  and  infrastructure  or  none  at
all. According to the comprehensive household survey undertaken in preparation for the Project,
there is an overwhelming demand by urban households, to improve their housing conditions and
take  loans  to  do  so.  About  91  percent  of  the  respondents  across  six  categories  of  housing
wanted to improve their housing conditions and about 80 percent of these would take loans to
do  so.  Through  different  lending  modalities,  the  Project  is  expected  to  directly  benefit  about

institutions such as private and public enterprises and medium- and small-scale contractors.

97.    Given  the  basic  linkage  between  improved  housing  and  human  welfare,  human
development  will  be  enhanced  by  the  provision  of  new  and/or  improved  housing  at  affordable
prices  and  with  meaningful  community  participation.  Although  many  of  the  benefits  that  will

Sustainability

106.    Establishing  a  full  market-based  sustainable  housing  finance  system  in  Mongolia  will
take some time. The HL, NHS and HPVTL and condominium assocation amendments passed
in  1999  have  established  a  market-oriented  legal  and  policy  framework  in  the  Mongolian
housing sector. Also, the recent amendments to the Civil Code with respect to use of immovable
property as collateral and granting authority to banks to possess the collateralized property from
borrowers  failing  to  repay  a  loan  provide  sufficient  safeguards  against  defaulters.  While  more
work is to be done, particularly, concerning the land legislation, the Project has several features
that strengthen the basis for accomplishing the long-term objective of establishing a sustainable
housing finance system in Mongolia. First, the establishment of a revolving fund at the HDF and
a commitment by PCBs to lend their own money help assure sustainability. Also, the difference
between the relending rate to PCBs and the cost of funds to the HDF will accrue to the HDF.
Second,  part  C  of  the  Project  will  significantly  strengthen  the  PCBs  to  undertake  mortgage
based  lending  so  that  direct  lending  to  individuals  can  be  started  by  year  three.  Until  the
capacity of the PCBs is sufficiently built, lending will be mainly to private and public enterprises
for on-lending to their employees. Third, the comprehensive policy dialogue agenda under the
Project  focuses  on  establishing  appropriate  and  sustainable  mechanisms  for  housing  finance.
Fourth, lending at market rates through PCBs, which are the only institutions with experience in
loan  origination  and  recovery  procedures,  represents  the  best  mechanism  for  building  a
sustainable  housing  finance  system.  Finally,  making  the  passage  of  the  new  land  law  a
condition for loan disbursement to individuals will further strengthen sustainability of the Project.

107.    The Project is designed to have long-term benefits by improving the quality of life of an
ever-increasing  portion  of  the  population  in  need  of  improved  shelter  and  urban  services.  The
establishment  of  a  sustainable  housing  finance  system  will  open  new  markets  for  the  banking
sector  and  strengthen  small-  and  medium-scale  contractors  to  provide  affordable  housing  to
low- and middle-income families. Key conditions for sustainability of the Project will be the ability
of PCBs to assimilate housing finance skills so that they will begin to increasingly lend their own
funds to public and private enterprises and individual borrowers; the ability and commitment of
lending  intermediaries  and  individual  borrowers  to  effectively  use  the  funds  for  housing
purposes;  the  ability  of  the  PMU  to  attract,  train,  and  retain  qualified  staff;  and  effective
communication to subborrowers of the terms and conditions of borrowing so that they repay in a
timely manner. To achieve these conditions, on-lending arrangements have been structured to
provide the PCBs with sufficient spreads to cover their operating costs and risk premiums and
provide an adequate margin. Semiannual reviews of on-lending and relending rates have been
provided  to  avoid  asset-liability  mismatches,  especially  if  inflation  recurs  during  the  Project
period or rate levels decline precipitously. Upon completion of project implementation, the PCBs
are  expected  to  be  making  housing  loans  primarily  with  their  own  resources.  In  addition,  the
establishment  of  a  substantial  revolving  fund  at  the  HDF  could  allow  the  HDF  to  evolve  into
housing bank by refinancing PCB loans, i.e., taking PCBs out of their primary loans, rather than
relending directly to them.

108.    Part  B  of  the  Project  will  achieve  sustainability  if,  upon  completion  of  Project
implementation,  (i)  the  HDF  continues  to  make  loans  to  local  governments  for  new  sites  and
upgrading  HAAPs  based  on  successful  implementation  of  previous  HAAP  subprojects,  (ii)
HAAP  subprojects  have  been  successfully  integrated  into  new  master  plans  for  Mongolian

part B, a proposal is being prepared for financing under the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction
(JFPR).  The  JFPR  Project  will  help  strengthen  the  financial  capability  of  HAAP  upgrading

community  income  generation  centers  to  help  poor  households;  (iii)  the  financing  for
establishing community-operated bathhouses, greenhouses, and women’s workshops; and (iv)
the financing for community training and capacity building to sustain economic development and
encourage additional improvements in the future.45

110.    As  a  result  of  the  Project,  the  increased  employment  opportunities  and  income  during

less school absenteeism, and less time at medical clinics and therefore reduced medical costs.
The  actual  tangible  and  intangible  benefits  to  the  poor  may  be  greater,  as  these  families  are

and enforcement of loan collateral; (iii) effectiveness of the Project to target loans to the most
deserving; and (iv) effective replication of the HAAP approach for community improvement and
planning.

112.    The problems of the banking system have been well documented in preparing this and
related  ADB-financed  projects.  With  the  support  of  ADB  and  World  Bank  TA,  the  banking
system  has  made  significant  progress  toward  becoming  a  viable  tool  for  the  country’s
development. Although the banking system has little or no experience with term lending, many
bank  managers  have  acquired  the  necessary  asset-liability  management  and  credit  design
skills,  including  well-documented  loan  agreements  that  are  required  for  successful  banking.

113.    Sustainable  housing  finance  markets  are  based  on  the  collateral  value  of  the  property
being  financed,  as  well  as  the  ability  of  the  lender  to  take  possession  and  dispose  of  the
property. The passage, in January 2001, of the amendment to the Civil Code allowing banks to
effectively  possess  and  dispose  of  loan  collateral  will  greatly  improve  the  functioning  of
Mongolia’s  financial  markets,  especially  housing  finance.    In  addition,  due  to  the  lack  of
individual household collateral as well as land titles or leases, the Project has been designed for
most  loans  to  be  lent  initially  through  private  and  public  enterprises  that  possess  adequate
collateral to guarantee their loans. To increase the supply of units for these entities, loans will
also be made to small- and medium-scale contractors for which the houses themselves will be
the collateral. Under part C of the Project, institutional strengthening will be provided to PCBs in
housing loan origination, underwriting, and collection to ensure the successful implementation of
the Project.

114.    Field surveys for the Project have found a pervasive desire among urban households to
improve  their  housing  situation  through  housing  loans.  The  Project  will  develop  strict  lending
guidelines for PCBs and intermediaries including rigorous selection criteria to ensure loans go to
the target beneficiaries of low- and middle-income households. Based on affordability, housing
need, and  area  of residence, such guidelines will give priority to households that presently do
not have dwellings and are doubled up with family and relatives.

115.    The  HAAP  approach  to  upgrading  ger  housing  area  communities  and  planning  new
residential sites is a new concept in Mongolia. The basic precept of the HAAP approach is that
ger housing communities are a permanent feature of the Mongolian urban landscape and, given
adequate  infrastructure  and  services,  can  be  developed  into  viable  residential  areas.  This
precept is also contained in the HL and is a basic policy component of the present Government.
Implementation  of  the  HAAP  approach  is  based  on  the  priorities  of  the  target  communities  as
well as a close partnership with the local governments. Such partnerships have been forged for
the  pilot  HAAP  schemes  in  Darkhan  and  Zuunmod.  The  Project  includes  comprehensive
workshops  to  continually  educate  city  architects  and  local  and  central  Government  leaders  to
promote  the  adoption  and  replication  of  the  HAAP  approach  to  community  planning  and
development.

of  water  supply,  drainage,  sanitation,  and  solid  waste  removal  are  the  primary  causes  of
hepatitis A, respiratory, digestive, genito-urinary, and skin diseases in Mongolia. The improved
housing  and  related  infrastructure  and  services  developed  by  the  Project  can  lead  to  better
water supply, sanitation, drainage, and waste collection, which would reduce the mortality and
morbidity  rates  due  to  these  diseases  among  the  beneficiaries,  particularly  the  poor,  who  are
more  vulnerable  to  disease  and  have  less  money  for  treatment.  The  economic  benefits  in
conjunction with the reduction in health problems will in turn result in savings in terms of fewer
days  of  absence  from  work,  less  loss  of  school  days,  reduced  medical  costs,  and  decreased
human suffering.

10.    The  incidence  of  housing  and  sanitation-related  diseases  in  Mongolia  stands  at  1,643
persons  per  10,000.7  An  average  of  14  days  of  hospitalization  is  required  for  the  treatment  of
each  illness.  The  average  cost  of  hospitalization  (including  drugs)  is  approximately  $2.64
(MNT2,901) per day.8 Assuming that the improvement could result in a 50 percent reduction of
morbidity,9  the  savings  in  medical  costs  for  the  beneficiary  population  as  a  whole  would  be
around $95,860 (MNT105.35 million) per year, while the savings in foregone income associated
with  absence  from  work  would  be  some  $67,200  (MNT73.8  million)  per  year.  Assuming  an
equal distribution of the benefits among the beneficiary population of 31,570, the poor will derive
an annual savings of $69,810 (MNT76.7 million) or $5.16 (MNT5,670) per person per year from
savings  in  medical  costs  and  foregone  income.10  The  fact  that  women  bear  disproportionate
household  responsibilities  for  cooking,  laundering,  fetching  water,  and  cleaning  implies  higher
gains for them from improvements in housing conditions and related infrastructure and services.
Children, who are more susceptible to infectious diseases, will also benefit.11

Labor and Cost Savings

12.    Piped  water  to  water  kiosks  will  be  provided  to  7,000  households  under  part  B  of  the
Project.  One  obvious  benefit  of  the  improvement  will  be  labor  savings  in  obtaining  water  for
these families.

13.    Each ger area family currently spends an average of 1.5 hours daily13 to get water from
kiosks  serviced  by  water  trucks.  Water  trucks  deliver  water  only  five  days  a  week,  which
requires  families  to  travel  even  farther  for  water  on  the  two  other  days.  The  effort  requires  an
additional  four  hours  of  travel  time  per  week  to  obtain  water  simply  to  meet  basic  household
needs.14 Providing piped water to kiosks under the Project will ensure the availability of water on
a  daily  basis  and  eliminate  the  need  for  the  additional  four  hours  per  family  per  week.  The
savings  in  time  on  an  annual  basis  would  amount  to  one  person-month  for  each  of  the  7,000
families. Assuming that the amount of time saved is used for productive purposes, the resulting
one person-month of saved labor could generate an average earning of $40 (MNT43,960) per
family,15 including the poor.

14.    The  supply  of  piped  water  can  also  reduce  the  price  of  water  by  half  from  MNT1.2  to
MNT0.6 per liter.16 The average monthly household cost of water in the surveyed ger housing
areas  was  approximately  $2.35  (MNT2,583).17    Households  above  and  under  the  poverty  line
spend approximately the same amount on water. Based on this low level of consumption, a poor
family could save $14 (MNT15,386) per year on water costs.
